description: Borrowed from Middle French impulser, from Latin impulsus.
For spelling, as in pulse, the -e (on -lse) is so the end is pronounced /ls/, rather than /lz/ as in pulls, and does not change the vowel (‘u’). Compare else, false, convulse.

entries.meaning: A thrust; a push; a sudden force that impels.
examples: All spontaneous animal motion is performed by mechanical impulse.

entries.meaning: A wish or urge, particularly a sudden one prompting action.
examples: The impulse to learn drove me to study night and day.
When I saw the new book, I couldn't resist the impulse to browse through it.

entries.meaning: (physics) The integral of force over time.
examples: The total impulse from the impact will depend on the kinetic energy of the projectile.

verbs.description: impulse (third-person singular simple present impulses, present participle impulsing, simple past and past participle impulsed)
